intro: Cedrela tonduzii, commonly known as the Brazilian cedar, is a tropical evergreen tree native to Central and South America. It belongs to the family Meliaceae and is characterized by its straight, durable wood that is highly valued in the timber industry. The tree typically grows to a height of 20–30 meters and has compound leaves with alternate arrangement. Its flowers are small and inconspicuous, while the fruit is a capsule that splits open to release winged seeds. Cedrela tonduzii plays an important ecological role in its native habitats, providing habitat for various wildlife species.
